messageBody:
Hi,

On Tuesday 27 July 2004 06:51, Singh, Kanwaljit wrote:
> Is there any documentation available on how to use Test Listeners in
> Junit.
I guess the Javadoc and / or the source is the best documentation
available.

> I wanted to know more about how to exactly write test listenrs for
> Junit. (I want to trigger some events based on the output of individual
> test cases as and when the output of a test case is available).
I never had the need for one.
I am not sure, whether doing something on the output of a test is a good
way to go. (At least JB didn't write about that in Junit Recipes, so it
can't be good ;-))

Why don't your tests signal whatever conditions you want to signal in a
more Java-like way? Like throwing, returning some value, or setting state
in an object.
If you want to check the output of code under test -- why don't you do
that in the test itself, using assertEquals or something like that?
You may have to change the tested code to accept an OutputStream and write
to that, rather than write hard-coded to System.out. In the production
code you can still pass System.out, and in the tests you pass a
ByteArrayOutputStream and check its contents later in the test code.
See also http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm#tests_4

Does that help?

Robert
